Courthouse favorite Gavi's Restaurant to close

Andrew Wolfson, The Courier-Journal 9:24 a.m. EST November 21, 2014
Buy Photo

Long-time Gavi's Restaurant customer Bill Adams, an assistant Commonwealth attorney, shares a laugh with Zina Gavi at the check-out counter following his lunch Thursday. Adams started coming to the restaurant eight years ago and eats at the downtown location at least four-times-a-week. "It's a nice comfortable place to go," Adams said. "I rarely go anywhere else." Like many of the restaurant's customers Adams is sad to learn that it will be closing. "I'm just disappointed," Adams said. Nov. 20, 2014(Photo: Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

42 CONNECT 4 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

They served Russian and Jewish favorites like borscht and Matzoh ball soup, along with more standard fare like fries and cheeseburgers.

But Gavi's most loyal customers came to hear their stories as much as for the food: How Ida and Joseph Gavi escaped the Holocaust. How Joseph fought the Nazis as a 10 year old. How he became a fearless mountain climber.

Opened 32 years ago in a modest space slightly below ground across from the Louisville police station, Gavi's Restaurant became a second home for defense lawyers, prosecutors, cops and judges.

But on Thursday, Joseph and Ida's grandsons, Gaba and David, announced that it is closing at the end of the year — news that saddened its customers.

"I don't know where I'll go," said family lawyer Jason Dattilo, who added he's eaten lunch at the restaurant on Seventh Street every weekday for five years and calls himself the restaurant's "self-proclaimed No. 1 customer."

"It is like Cheers," he said. "Everybody knows your name."

Jefferson Circuit Court Judge McKay Chauvin called the restaurant a "local institution that is part of the extended courthouse family" and likened it to Rick's American Cafe in the movie "Casablanca," where "people of all stripes share space and a meal."

COURIER-JOURNAL

Middletown apartment's alcohol sales nixed

His colleague, Judge Barry Willett, who shared a table with Chauvin and a reporter Thursday, said: "It doesn't matter if you're a CEO or a garbage collector. Everybody is treated the same."

Announcing the restaurant's demise in a press release, Gaba, 32, said it has been "more than simply a place to eat, it has been a place to share in the human experience."

He said he and David, 36, are looking to explore some new opportunities, which he declined to identify. "We've got an open plate," he said, no pun intended.

Their mother, Zina, 64, and grandmother, Ida, who is 80, say they will retire.

"We are grateful to all the patrons that have stepped through the doors over the years," Gaba said in the release, "and wish the best to those who continue to be friends."

The restaurant was so much a part of the legal community that in 1998 it was the scene of an undercover sting operation in which a lawyer was recorded on video as she allegedly passed on $100 to bribe a West Buechel police officer to fix a drunken-driving case. The lawyer was acquitted at trial.

    The restaurant's lease in Advocacy Plaza expired in October but was extended through December, said Tim Mulloy, whose family owns the building that also houses the public defender's office.

    He said Mulloy Properties hopes to find another restaurant for the space, which was home to Mazzoni's Oyster Cafe before Gavi's opened in 1982.

    "They have been a wonderful tenant," Mulloy said. "Louisville has been a better place for them." He said it was particularly a privilege to meet Joseph Gavi, who died in 2002, and whom Mulloy described as a "walking-around piece of history."

    Gavi, who stood 4 feet, 11 inches tall as an adult, was so small as a child that he could escape through gaps in walls and fences, allowing him to guide 200 to 300 people from the Minsk ghetto, in what is now Belarus, into the safety of a nearby forest, Western Kentucky University history professor Carlton Jackson wrote in a book about him. Among the people he rescued were his mother and brother; Gavi's father, grandparents and about 35 other relatives did not get out and died there.

    Gavi shared with customers his other adventures — how he joined the Russian navy as a teenager, became a champion Greco-Roman wrestler, earned his doctorate in physiology, took up mountain climbing and helped train Soviet soldiers each summer in the Caucasus Mountains, before emigrating with Ida to the United States in 1978.

    "In the old country, he had to watch very carefully what he said to people," Jackson said a few years ago. "He always said he was catching up on his First Amendment rights in his restaurant."

    Gavi, whose heroism was recognized by the Kentucky Senate about a year before he died, also said at Holocaust remembrances that survivors should "never wait to tell their stories.

    "As soon as we forget," he said, "it's possible to happen again."

    Customers came to hear his stories — and those of Ida, Zina and her children.

    "I went to Gavi's because I loved the family," said County Attorney Mike O'Connell.

    On Thursday, Ida reminisced, showing black-and-white family photographs to customers, including one of her and Joseph on horseback as they guided Soviet mapmakers through the mountains of Uzbekistan.

    Buy Photo

    Joseph Gavi in 1995.(Photo: Keith Williams/The C-J)

    "I'm sad," she said of the closing. "This has been half my life. We started with zilch and we made a living."

    Zina tried to deflect questions about the restaurant's demise.

    "Are you going to make me cry now?" she asked to one customer as he paid his bill at the register.

    Dattilo bemoaned the loss of the last of the courthouse hangouts, which once included the fabled Holly's Legal Street Lounge and Delta Lounge.

    Criminal defense lawyer Chris Klein, 49, who started eating at Gavi's in 1991 as a young public defender, asked, "Where else are you going to get a grill cheese and tomato sandwich on whole wheat — without even having to ask for it?"

    Willett said he'll miss even the family squabbles that played out behind the counter.

    "You could always tell when they were mad, because they would speak in Russian," he said.

    Chauvin said Gavi's felt like family.

    "Zina would even yell at you you if you didn't eat your vegetables."
